tit.e: Kogo-ishi (rows of stones arranged on mountain slopes in Kyushu and Western Japan)
Kogo-ishi (rows of stones arranged on mountain slopes in Kyushu and Western Japan)
tit.cmt: タイトルの為、説明を削除。

sen.j: 神籠石（こうごいし）または神籠石式山城（こうごいししきやましろ）とは古代に築造された山城で、「日本書紀」「続日本紀」に記載がなく、遺構でしか存在の確認できないものを指す。
sen.e: Kogo-ishi or kogo-ishi-style castle on the mountain refers to the castle built on the mountain in ancient times, has no description in "Nihon shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and "Zoku Nihon shoki" (the sequel to Chronicles of Japan) and can be identified only as its remains.

Kogo-ishi or kogo-ishi-style mountain castles were castles built on mountains in ancient times, and because there is no description of them in the "Nihon shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) or "Zoku Nihon shoki" (the sequel to Chronicles of Japan) they can be identified only through remains.

sen.j: 古代山城（朝鮮式山城）の比定地にされることもあるが、築造主体など建設の経緯は一切不明である。
sen.e: It is sometimes supposed as the place for the ancient castle on the mountain (Korean-style castle on the mountain), but the process of construction such as the construction client and so on remains totally unknown.
They have been identified as the surmised locations of ancient mountain castles (Korean-style mountain castles), but the process of construction and who they were built for is totally unknown.

sen.j: 特色は、標高200～400mの山頂から中腹にかけて数kmにわたって一辺が70cm位の切石（きりいし＝岩を割って作った石）による石積みを配列し、谷を通過するときには水門を設けていること。
sen.e: On the mountains which are 200-400 meters high, it characteristically arranged "kiriishi" (stones made by breaking the rocks) which are about 70 centimeters wide, from the top to the middle of the mountain slope which are some kilometers long, and where passing through the valley, it had a water gate.

Their characteristics are that on mountains which are 200-400 meters high, "kiriishi" (stones made by breaking rocks) about 70 centimeters wide, were placed from the top to the middle of the mountain, running for several kilometers, and which had a water gate when passing through a valley.

sen.j: 八木奘三郎は、古墳石室の構築法との比較から、神籠石の築造年代は推古朝（7世紀初）以前としている。
sen.e: Sozaburo YAGI estimated that kogo-ishi had firstly been built before the early seventh century by comparison with the method of construction of tumulus stone chamber.
Sozaburo YAGI estimated that kogo-ishi had initially been built before the early seventh century through a comparison of the method of construction of tumulus stone chambers.

sen.j: 鏡山猛は、列石前面の掘立柱穴の間隔が約3mで並んでおり、唐尺（一尺＝29.5cm）の十尺（2.95m）とほぼ等しいことから唐尺が使われた7世紀中頃以降の築造とした。
sen.e: Takeshi KAGAMIYAMA estimated that kogo-ishi had been built after the middle of the seventh century because the gap between the holes for posts in front of the arranged stones was about three meters and nearly equal to ten shaku (2.95 meters) by "toshaku" (unit of measurement during the period of Tang Dynasty in China) which was used during the middle of the seventh century.

sen.j: 北部九州から瀬戸内沿岸にかけて、16箇所が知られる。
sen.e: Sixteen remains of kogo-ishi are known to be located from the north Kyushu to the Setouchi seacost.
The location of the remains of sixteen kogo-ishi are known, stretching from northern Kyushu to the Setouchi seacoast.

sen.j: 神籠石が学会に発表されたのは、明治31年に小林庄次郎が筑後・高良山神籠石を「霊地として神聖に保たれた地を区別したもの」として紹介したのが最初。
sen.e: In 1898 Shojiro KOBAYASHI introduced the kogo-ishi in Mt. Chikugo-Kora as 'the sacred place which was holily preserved and distinguished,' which was firstly presented to the academy.

sen.j: 明治33年に九州所在の神籠石を踏査した八木奬三郎が「城郭を除いては、他にこの類の大工事なかるべし」として城郭であることを主張して以後、この神籠石の性格について霊域説と城郭説との論争が展開された。
sen.e: In 1900 Sozaburo YAGI explored the kogo-ishi located in Kyushu region and insisted, 'These kinds of large constructions were never done except for castles' and after that, the dispute between the sacred-place theory and the castle theory concerning the characteristics of kogo-ishi continued.

In 1900 Sozaburo YAGI explored the kogo-ishi located in the Kyushu region and insisted that, 'these kinds of large constructions only appear as part of castles' and after that, the dispute between the sacred-place theory and the castle theory began.

sen.j: 昭和38年（1963年）の佐賀県武雄市「おつぼ山」神籠石の発掘調査で、列石の背後にある版築によって築かれた土塁と、列石の前面に3m間隔で並ぶ堀立柱の痕跡が発見され、山城であることが確定的となった。
sen.e: In the excavation and research of "Mt. Otsubo" kogo-isi in Takeo city in Saga prefecture in 1963, the dorui (earthwork) built by "hanchiku" (construction method for solidifying the basic part) behind the arranged stones and the traces of the posts which was aligned at three meters interval in front of the arranged stones were discovered and as a result, kogo-ishi came to be determinately considered as a castle on the mountain.

During the excavation and research of the "Mt. Otsubo" kogo-ishi in Takeo city in Saga prefecture in 1963, the dorui (earthwork) built using the "hanchiku" construction method behind the arranged stones, and the traces of posts aligned at three-meter intervals in front of the arranged stones were discovered, and as a result it was widely accepted that kogo-ishi were mountain castles.

sen.j: 御所ヶ谷のように「最初期形成時代以降にかなりの手が入っていると思われるもの」や、雷山のように「生活域、食料生産域との隔絶性が高く、水も確保しづらく、籠城に向かず、、祭祀遺跡との位置関係が特殊であるもの」、おつぼ山のように「稲作農耕地域の小丘陵に設置されているもの」などである。
sen.e: There are 'the one which seems to have been repeatedly reconstructed since the earliest formation period' as in Goshogatani, 'the one which was very far from the living space and food-production area, could not easily ensure water, inadequate for taking refuge and unusual in the positional relation with the remains of shrine place' as in Mt. Rai, 'the one located on a small hill where was the area of rice cropping and agriculture' as in Mt. Otsubo and so on.

There are those such as Goshogatani which seem to have been repeatedly reconstructed, others such as Mt. Rai which are very far from the living space and food-production areas, which could not easily provide water, were inadequate for taking refuge and unusual in their position in relation to the sacred area, and those such as Mt Otsubo located on a small hill with an area of rice cultivation and agriculture.

sen.j: 現在まで、神籠石が何時頃作られたかも判明しておらず、成立年代は同じであったとしても、これほど様々に状況の違うものを現在的視点から神籠石と総称している可能性は高い。
sen.e: When kogo-ishi was made has been unknown until now and even if the completion times wrere same, considering such wide varieties of the situation from a present viewpoint, it is highly possible that we collectively refer to them as kogo-ishi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is unclear as to when the kogo-ishi were built, and even if they are of the same era it is probable that we only collectively refer to the wide variety of constructions as 'kogo-ishi' based on the distorting prism of what remains today.

sen.j: また、仮にこれらすべてが単純に古代山城であった場合でも、それらが戦略拠点たりえた状況を含めて、そのようなものが西日本の広範な地域に存在していること、現在までほとんど知られていなかったことは、大和王朝成立前後や、その過程の古代史を考える上で非常に重要なはずである。
sen.e: Also, even if all of these were just an ancient castle on the mountain, they exist in the broad area of the western Japan, have been nearly unknown until now and could be strategic points, which should be very important in considering the period around the formation of Yamato Dynasty or the ancient history of those processes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Also, even if all of these were simply ancient mountain castles, as they exist in a broad area of western Japan in potentially strategic positions and have been nearly unknown until now, they are historically important when considering the period around the formation of Yamato Dynasty and the process of its creation.

sen.j: しかし、現代（21世紀初頭）の歴史研究を取り巻く環境の中で強い興味を持って捉えられることは少ないことから、歴史がどのように形成されていくのかを現代に於いて知る極めて有効な事例であるとの声もある。
sen.e: However, in the circumstances surrounding the present-day (the early 21st century) historical study, they are not very attractive, but some say that they are very useful case examples because we can know how the history is formulated in modern times.
